TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , suspected of theft , was allegedly subjected to a beating by police officers in police station no . CARDINAL in PERSON . Later he was taken to ORG , where several police officers allegedly handcuffed him , put a gas mask over his face and beat him with batons and a metal chair for TIME .

CARDINAL . In TIME of CARDINAL November CARDINAL he was locked in a cell , where he spent DATE . During DATE he lost consciousness several times and asked for medical assistance . At TIME the applicant was taken to a hospital where he was diagnosed with multiple bruises on his face , a fracture of the left shin and a head trauma with concussion .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was taken to a forensic medical institution for examination . He was diagnosed with multiple bruises on his face , chest , legs and buttocks , a fracture of the left shin and a head trauma with concussion . The medical report stated that :

“ The [ applicant ’s ] injuries were inflicted by blows with blunt objects with a limited surface area ( au fost cauzate în rezultatul acţiunii traumatice de un corp contondent cu suprafaţa limitată de interacţiune ) ...
It can not be excluded that the fracture [ of the left shin ] ... was caused as a result of [ the applicant ’s ] fall from a height . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained to ORG about the ill - treatment to which he had been subjected and requested that the police officers who had ill - treated him be prosecuted .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s complaint as manifestly ill - founded . The prosecutor had questioned the applicant , who had reiterated his complaints . He had also questioned CARDINAL police officers accused of ill - treatment , who had declared that on DATE the applicant had attempted to escape from the police station by jumping from the window of a toilet on the second floor . The prosecutor concluded that all of the injuries on the applicant ’s body resulted from his fall .

CARDINAL . The applicant challenged the prosecutor ’s decision before ORG and argued , inter alia , that he had never jumped from the window of the toilet of the police station and that there was no window in that toilet . Moreover , the forensic medical report concluded that only the fracture of his shin could have been caused by a fall .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE ORG upheld his appeal . The court relied on the forensic medical report , which found that most of the applicant ’s injuries could only have been caused by blows , and on the applicant ’s submission that there was no window in the toilet of the police station .

CARDINAL . On DATE Prosecutor PERSON from ORG again dismissed the applicant ’s complaint about ill - treatment . The prosecutor again questioned the police officers accused of ill - treatment , who repeated their account of the applicant ’s jump from the window . This time the police officers added that after jumping from the window and breaking his shin , the applicant had attempted to escape and resisted arrest and that they had been forced to apply force and special techniques , thus causing the other injuries on his body . The prosecutor also questioned a third party , who worked in an office in the police station and who confirmed the accounts of the police officers . The third party also added that he had heard the applicant shout that he would mutilate himself in order to accuse the police later of ill - treatment . Finally , the prosecutor stated that he had checked the toilet of the police station on the second floor and had found that it had a large window .

CARDINAL . The applicant challenged the prosecutor ’s decision before ORG and the investigation was reopened . A further forensic report dated DATE was obtained , which excluded the possibility that all the injuries on the applicant ’s body could have been sustained as a result of a jump from the height of the second floor or DATE from the applicant ’s own height .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG indicted the CARDINAL police officers accused of ill - treating the applicant and DATE referred the case to a court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found the accused police officers guilty of acts of torture in respect of the applicant . The court relied on the forensic reports which contradicted the police ORG version of events concerning the origin of the applicant ’s injuries and relied on the testimony of a witness who had heard sounds of ill - treatment and shouts from the office where the applicant was questioned and who had seen the applicant lying on the floor when the door opened . The police officers were given a suspended sentence of DATE imprisonment and banned from working at ORG for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed the appeals lodged by ORG , the applicant and the accused police officers and upheld the judgment of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the appeal on points of law lodged by ORG and ordered the reopening of the proceedings before ORG . It found , inter alia , that the sanction imposed on the accused police officers was too lenient .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG re - examined the appeal against the judgment of DATE and acquitted the accused police officers . The ORG has not been provided with a copy of the judgment of ORG . ORG appealed against that judgment and on an unspecified date ORG quashed the judgment of DATE and ordered a fresh examination by ORG of the appeal against the judgment of DATE .
